results.snippet: Joe H. Engle has retired from active duty as an Air Force colonel and has also resigned from the astronaut corps, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.
results.lead_paragraph: Joe H. Engle has retired from active duty as an Air Force colonel and has also resigned from the astronaut corps, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

results.snippet: Peace Links, an organization led by 130 wives of members of Congress, held its first fund event the other night in the ballroom of the Capital Hilton Hotel. Billed as the Peace on Earth Gala, it included dancing to the music of Peter Du-chin's...

byline.original: By Wayne King and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: Peace Links, an organization led by 130 wives of members of Congress, held its first fund event the other night in the ballroom of the Capital Hilton Hotel. Billed as the Peace on Earth Gala, it included dancing to the music of Peter Du-chin's orchestra. Russell Schweickart, a former astronaut who was the evening's principal speaker, looked up at those in the elegant crowd who had paid $250 a ticket and said, ''This is one of the few times I've seen peace people actually having fun.''

results.snippet: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology dedicated its space studies building Friday to Ronald E. McNair, one of seven astronauts killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded in January. The six-story concrete building near the center of the...
results.lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology dedicated its space studies building Friday to Ronald E. McNair, one of seven astronauts killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded in January. The six-story concrete building near the center of the campus houses 100,000 square feet of classrooms, laboratories and offices dedicated to ''reaching, exploring, understanding and operating in space,'' Paul Gray, the school's president, said.

headline.main: NASA CHIEF MIGHT NOT TAKE PART IN DECISIONS ON BOOSTER CONTRACTS

results.snippet: Dr. James C. Fletcher, the NASA Administrator who awarded the contract for the space shuttle rockets that led to the Challenger disaster, says that he will ''seriously consider'' removing himself from all future determinations on shuttle booster...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. James C. Fletcher, the NASA Administrator who awarded the contract for the space shuttle rockets that led to the Challenger disaster, says that he will ''seriously consider'' removing himself from all future determinations on shuttle booster contracts. His statement came in an interview on Friday after he heard a review of accusations, made by Senator Ernest F. Hollings, competitive contractors and various aerospace experts, that his original decision could appear to have been biased in favor of a Utah company. Dr. Fletcher insisted that the decision was ''squeaky clean'' and was made on its technical merits, containing no hint of personal favoritism. He said he did not recall any questions of bias being raised in 1973, when the contract for the shuttle booster rockets was awarded to Morton Thiokol Inc. of Brigham City, Utah. Review of Booster Decision Dr. Fletcher, appointed again this year to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, spoke in reaction, also, to information contained in newly disclosed or re-examined documents and provided in dozens of interviews, part of an investigation by The New York Times over the past several months into the origins and loss of the Challenger.

headline.main: U.S. Heads Down the Road to Scientific Dotage

results.snippet: To the Editor:   For a good part of this century, the United States has basked in the bright light of scientific and technological achievement. Scientists and engineers in universities and industry have produced a steady stream of discoveries and...
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: For a good part of this century, the United States has basked in the bright light of scientific and technological achievement. Scientists and engineers in universities and industry have produced a steady stream of discoveries and innovations that have earned this country international recognition for creativity. In the last three decades, other countries have gradually emerged to challenge this pre-eminence. Strong research and development programs, some subsidized directly or indirectly by governments, have resulted in the creation of a cadre of scientists and engineers whose contributions have earned the respect of the industrialized world.

results.snippet: IN the Barbie aisle at the toy store under false pretenses. Around me there is a feeding frenzy: over the glow-in-the-dark ball gown, the wicker furniture, over Barbie's video recording studio and her Corvette. ''Has anyone seen the hot tub?'' asks...
results.lead_paragraph: IN the Barbie aisle at the toy store under false pretenses. Around me there is a feeding frenzy: over the glow-in-the-dark ball gown, the wicker furniture, over Barbie's video recording studio and her Corvette. ''Has anyone seen the hot tub?'' asks one mother plaintively. ''I need the hot tub.'' Where there were hot tubs, there is now only an empty place on the shelf. On one side of the aisle the Barbies stand behind cellophane, in ball gowns, in bathing suits, in exercise clothes, as perky as the Dallas Cowboy cheerleaders when the television cameras are whirring away.

headline.main: INDIA CARRIES ITS DREAMS INTO SPACE

results.snippet: AFTER two decades of dreaming, planning and development, India's space program has come of age. Once merely a symbol of the nation's pride and ingenuity, Indian space technology has become an integral part of its communications, weather forecasting...
results.lead_paragraph: AFTER two decades of dreaming, planning and development, India's space program has come of age. Once merely a symbol of the nation's pride and ingenuity, Indian space technology has become an integral part of its communications, weather forecasting and resource management systems. ''We started modestly and built step by step,'' said U. R. Rao, director of the Indian space program. ''There was a lot of criticism along the way. But today everyone is convinced that this is the best way to meet the country's needs.'' A few major developing countries, such as Brazil and China, have also developed space technology, principally for military purposes. But Western scientists say that no other country outside the United States, Europe and the Soviet Union has achieved India's broad and deep ability to use space in civilian life. Scientists say India offers a case study of how a developing country can exploit advanced technology to meet fundamental needs.

headline.main: SHUTTLE CHANGING IN EXTENSIVE WAYS TO FOSTER SAFETY

results.snippet: Piece by painstaking piece, NASA is revamping the space shuttle system that disintegrated, along with a good measure of the nation's technological self-confidence, 11 months ago today.   The next shuttle orbiter that astronauts clamber into on the...
results.lead_paragraph: Piece by painstaking piece, NASA is revamping the space shuttle system that disintegrated, along with a good measure of the nation's technological self-confidence, 11 months ago today. The next shuttle orbiter that astronauts clamber into on the Kennedy Space Center launching pad will probably include a crude but effective escape system for them to use in case disaster strikes again. Its landing brakes will be improved. Its main liquid fuel engines will be upgraded, and for the first time astronauts may fly without harboring the seldom-spoken fear that a malfunction in a simple 17-inch valve could choke off the craft's liquid fuel supply and send it crashing into the sea. Much Safer Craft Is Seen The safety changes being made by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration thus go far beyond the redesigning of the solid-fuel booster rocket whose failure killed seven astronauts 73 seconds into the flight of the Challenger last Jan. 28. While the debate over how to redesign those boosters has drawn much attention, both agency officials and outside experts are concerned that other critical elements of the shuttle may have been neglected amid the pressures to keep flying that contributed to the Challenger's destruction.

headline.main: REBUILT NASA 'ON WAY BACK' AS AN ARRAY OF DOUBTS PERSIST

results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has made substantial progress in carrying out the most extensive managerial and technical review in its history, according to space officials and outside experts.   The agency appears well on its...

byline.original: By PHILIP M. BOFFEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has made substantial progress in carrying out the most extensive managerial and technical review in its history, according to space officials and outside experts. The agency appears well on its way to repairing defects blamed for the disaster last January that grounded the space shuttles. And it has begun to reorganize its faulty management structure along the lines recommended by the Presidential commission that investigated the accident, which killed the seven Challenger crew members. In only 11 months, a vast majority of the top officials in shuttle operations have been replaced. NASA headquarters in Washington has a new Administrator, a new Deputy Administrator and a new Associate Administrator for Space Flight; the directors of NASA's three most important field centers have changed; and all the key engineering managers at the Marshall Space Flight Center who were faulted in the accident have been swept out.

headline.main: THREAT TO NATION'S LEAD IN SPACE IS SEEN IN LACK OF GUIDING POLICY

results.snippet: As workers at Cape Canaveral prepare for the somber task of burying the debris of the space shuttle Challenger in an abandoned missile silo, the greater wreckage of the American space program still lies everywhere, picked over but by no means...
results.lead_paragraph: As workers at Cape Canaveral prepare for the somber task of burying the debris of the space shuttle Challenger in an abandoned missile silo, the greater wreckage of the American space program still lies everywhere, picked over but by no means reassembled into a vibrant whole. Thus, 11 months after the worst disaster in spacefaring history, the United States finds itself well into the space age without a bold vision of where it is going and what it wants to achieve in space and without a coherent, comprehensive national policy guiding its diverse endeavors, according to aerospace experts, members of Congress and space officials. As a consequence, they say, the nation is in danger of forfeiting its position as the leader in space, a loss that could have economic and strategic implications well into the 21st century. The non-military space program, its many triumphs a receding memory, is especially seen as in grave danger. Visions and Realities Once there were manned voyages to the Moon, regular, unmanned departures for the distant planets and a fair wind of shared national commitment that seemed sure to carry those who ventured far beyond the Earth. Once there were dreams of bases on the Moon, humans tramping on the red plains of Mars. The dreams, it once seemed, were so manifestly achievable as to be less like visions than expressions of tomorrow's reality.

results.snippet: The Justice Department said yesterday that the families of four astronauts who died in the Challenger disaster had agreed to settle all claims against the Government, the space agency and its contractors in exchange for ''payments over an extended...
results.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said yesterday that the families of four astronauts who died in the Challenger disaster had agreed to settle all claims against the Government, the space agency and its contractors in exchange for ''payments over an extended period of time.'' Although the department named no figure, each family is said to be in line for at least $750,000. In a brief statement, the Justice Department said families of each of four astronauts - Francis R. Scobee, the mission commander, Air Force Lieut. Col. Ellison S. Onizuka, Gregory B. Jarvis and Christa McAuliffe, a New Hampshire schoolteacher - had agreed to settle ''all potential claims'' in the Challenger explosion, which also killed three other astronauts. Two other astronaut families have filed suits and a third has not taken any action.
